description.en: This is an advanced course in human rights providing an in-depth knowledge of selected issues. As it is an advanced course, it requires some pre-knowledge of human rights and their protection internationally and domestically.  The course involves case study of controversial human rights issues drawing mainly on material from regional and international human rights law and domestic legal systems of Europe and North America (US, Canada). It highlights some of the key controversies in modern human rights law, and the possible range of responses in different jurisdictions to controversial topics. The focus is on comparing reasoning in actual court cases and analyzing them in the larger human rights framework. The course as a whole will aim to provide the opportunity for in-depth comparative study, during which the appropriateness, utility and limits of the comparative legal techniques will be considered. The topics of the course may change every year.

objectives.en:
The goal of the course is to provide students with knowledge and skills to:
- understand and assess controversial/divisive human rights issues in comparative perspective and both in theory and in practice.
- understand human rights issues and judicial reasoning in the wider international and domestic context.
-conduct comparative case study on human rights issues
-present (in writing and orally) their papers and discuss their research in a conference-style framework

learning_outcomes.en:
Learning outcomes
A student who has passed the course:
- has the ability to identify and analyse key issues in the theory and practice of human rights.
- has the ability to analyse why there are different approaches and outcomes in different jurisdictions to selected rights.
- has a good knowledge of how selected human rights are implemented and applied in practice.
- understands the potential and the limitations of law as a tool to address human rights concerns.
- understands the potential and limitations of the comparative method in the practice of human rights.
- has practiced being a presenter, moderator, discussant and a panel member at the conference-style seminars dedicated to essay presentations and discussion
- has improved their analytical and writing skills on contemporary human rights issues

independent_work.et:
There are two components to the individual work: preparation for the seminar and essays.
1. You are expected to read materials given for each seminar. You should work through the material in a way to be able to give a short summary of the reading material in the class and express your opinion about what you have read. You will not be able to follow the seminar discussion if you have not read the relevant material. This material can be demanding, and you should allocate sufficient time to read it carefully. You should be using the seminar to test ideas about the reading you have done for that week.

2. You have to write an essay during the course, which is mandatory for the successful completition of the course. The essay should be related to the course content and it needs to have a comparative element. A selection of essay titles will be provided by your teacher. However, you can propose your own title. The essays should be no less than 2000 words long (including footnotes) and no more than 2500 words (including footnotes). The essays should be submitted a week before the seminar where you present your essay. The essays are assessed during the dedicated seminars for essay presentations and discussion where you get feedback from your teacher and fellow students. For that purpose you will prepare a short presentation of the main ideas expressed in the essay and be prepared to answer questions about your essay.

description.et: The research paper should be written on the topic covered in the seminars. The essay should be analytical (non-descriptive). It should address the essay question in a thorough, logical and coherent manner. The essay should be based on relevant and sufficient sources and materials to provide reasoned and convincing opinions on the matter under discussion. The essay must follow the style and citation guide adopted in the law faculty. It is important for the student to be able to defend/discuss his or her essay in the short presentation at the seminar dedicated to essay discussion, respond to questions and criticism. The assessment of fellow students' essays should be thorough, constructive and follow the instructions provided by your teacher.The discussion seminars will be held in the style of a conference where students participate as active moderators, discussants, presenters and panel members.

grade_preconditions.et: Active participation in all seminars, completed essay assignment and assessment of your fellow students  essays according to guidelines provided by your teacher. Your essay should be submitted a week before the seminar dedicated to your essay discussion to enable your teacher and fellow students to give you thorough feedback.

grade_evaluation.et:
1) A student has to actively participate in seminars, be able to give a short summary of the reading material, express opinions about the reading, and be able to point out problematic aspects of the topics covered in the reading. Additionally, active seminar participation includes thoroughly reading, providing constructive criticism and discussion of all essays written by fellow students. Essays are forwarded to students a week before assessment along with instructions on what to pay attention to when assessing/criticizing the essays.

2) The essay
The final grade is made up from 2 segments: essay- 50% and oral class presentation combined with activism in the class (50 %).
